learning_outcomes.description: Recognise design manufacturing principles, materials, and technologies in the design context, and their impact on broader systems.
Communicate product design ideas using technical drawing conventions.
Experiment with and apply introductory subtractive and additive prototyping techniques based on design briefs.
Use CAD models in digital fabrication processes to support prototyping and communicate design concepts.
Justify use of prototyping methods to address specific design requirements across various contexts.
Compile and communicate prototyping outcomes and design concepts using written, visual, and verbal methods appropriate to peer audiences.

assessments.due_date:
6/08/2025 - 22/10/2025

Weekly tasks due weeks: 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, 11, 12

Note: Week 3 task is due in week 4 (due to public holiday): Wednesday 20 August
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

In this design process assignment, you will document your design progression from the previous week using mixed multimedia formats. Specific outputs will be specified in the studio slides available on Blackboard. Upload your video, scans, and photos to an Instagram account. Your design process will be reviewed for feedback purposes and marked during class.

Tasks may include – Refer to specific tasks on Blackboard:

  • 5-10 second video. Quick overview showing: CAD work; Sketches; Prototyping
  • Sketching
  • Photos of prototyping

Complex / authentic assessment using AI and/or MT to support learning:  Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rational:

Model all three (3) components of your trophy designed for the Sustainability Design Award in Autodesk Fusion that utilises the capabilities of each advanced prototyping technology.

This is a 3-part submission that must include:

Part 1 – 3D Printed Form – 10%, DUE Week 5

  • You will use Autodesk Fusion to model the main form of your trophy that reflects your chosen design language.
  • The form must be modelled within the constraints of and optimised for FDM 3D printing.
  • Size must not exceed a volume of 70mmx70mmx150mm for 3d printing. The final form may be larger if assembly is implemented.
  • Files must be ready for processing in .STL format – Renamed using the following naming convention: lastname_firstname_DSGN1400_AT23DP_part#of#
  • Submit all native CAD file(s) and .STL file(s) in Blackboard.

Part 2 – CNC Base – 10%, DUE Week 7

  • You will use Autodesk Fusion to model a base for your trophy that reflects your chosen design language.
  • The base must be modelled within the constraints of CNC routing and with a CAM toolpath generated in Autodesk Fusion.
  • Size must not exceed a volume of 100mmx100mmx18mm
  • Files must be ready for processing in .DXF format – Renamed using the following naming convention: lastname_firstname_DSGN1400_AT23DP_part#of#.
  • Submit all native CAD file(s) and .DXF file(s)

Part 3 – Laser Cut Packaging – 10%, DUE Week 10

  • You will use Autodesk Fusion’s Sheet Metal tools to design packaging that reflects your chosen design language.
  • You will need to create a dieline of your design to be laser cut.
  • The size of the dieline must not exceed 750mmx500mm.
  • Files must be ready for processing in .DXF format – Renamed using the following naming convention: lastname_firstname_DSGN1400_AT23DP_part#of#.
  • Submit all native CAD file(s) and .DXF file(s) in Blackboard.

Complex / authentic assessment using AI and/or MT to support learning:  Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged. Uploaded files must contain readable text and not be rasterised. Students are advised to commence assignment uploads with sufficient amount of time (consider possible technical problems with computers, internet speed, etc). After successfully submitting an assignment through Turnitin, a ‘Submission Complete!’ screen will be displayed. It is the student’s responsibility to check assignment preview and confirm successful submission. If the ‘Submission Complete!’ screen isn’t displayed, the student should regard the submission as unsuccessful. Students should download a copy of the digital receipt as proof they have submitted the assignment. Students who are experiencing upload issues must advise the Course Coordinator immediately by email and should include screenshots and a copy of the assessment for submission. To meet professional accreditation, public engagement and quality assurance obligations, digital copies of all course assessment items must be submitted in addition to any hard copy submission requirements specified in individual Course / Studio Outlines. Any physical models should be photographed and a minimum of two photographs describing the complete and full model must be included in the digital submission.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

Submission Format: Digital Submission via Blackboard. Tangible outputs due in class.

In this project, you are invited to design and prototype a trophy for the esteemed Sustainable Design Award – A symbol of innovation, ethics, and environmental responsibility. This trophy isn’t simply an accolade but a narrative cast in form. Your task is to translate the values of sustainability into a tangible artefact that speaks not only of excellence in design, but of conscious creation.

You will submit your final physical trophy design with the following outputs:

An edited 3-minute video (Minimum video resolution: 1920×1080p Landscape OR Portrait) that covers your design process throughout this project, including:

  • a short introduction presented as a product pitch.
  • Overview of your entire design process – show your aesthetic vision from concept to execution.

Your assembled trophy, including the 3 elements covered in Assessment 2.

  • 3D printed form
  • CNC machined base
  • Laser cut packaging

Your design process journal as a compilation of all weekly tasks from Assessment 1

  • You are allowed to revise and improve the quality and amount of content until the due date.
  • Hand sketches should be scanned properly – Do not take photos of your pages.
  • Weeks should be clearly labelled to show weekly process.

Complex / authentic assessment using AI and/or MT to support learning:  Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
